div.l: Syk lay the maunciple on a maladye
Men wenden wisly that he shulde dye
For which the meller stale bothe mele and corn
An hundred tyme more than biforn
For ther biforn he stale but curteysly
But now he was a thef outrageously
For which the wardeyn chidde and made fare
But therof sette the meller not a tare
He crakide boost and swore it was not so
Thanne were there ȝong scolers two ·
That dwelten in the halle of which I seye
Testyf the were and lusty forto pleye
And oonly for her mirthe and reuerie
Vppon the wardeyn bisily thei crie
To ȝeue hem leue but a litel stounde
To go to melle and seen her corn grounde
And hardely thei dorste leye her nekke
The meller shulde not stele hem half a pekke
Of corn ne bi slight ne bi force hem Reue
And atte laste the wardeyn ȝaf hem leue
Iohn hight that oon and Aleyn hight that other
Of oon toun were thei born that hight strother
Fer in the North I can not telle where
This Aleyn makith redy al his gere
And on an hors the sak he caste anoon
Forth gooth Aleyn the Clerk and also Iohn
With good swerd and with bokeler bi his side
Iohn knew the weye hym nedid no gyde
And atte Milne the sak a doun he laith
Aleyn spak first · alhayl Symoıı̄un in faith
How fares thi faire doughter and thi wyf
Aleyn welcome qduod Symkyn bi my lyf
And Iohn also how now what do ȝe heere
Certis qduod Iohn · Symond nede has no pere
Hym bihoues serue him silf that has no swayn
Or ellis he is a fool as clerkis sayn
